text: I am data scientist at the Midwest Center of Excellence for Vector-Borne Disease (MCEVBD) https://mcevbd.wisc.edu/. I have a broad experience in behavioral research, database management, statistical modeling, and data visualization. I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

I enjoy being a resource for my colleagues and providing advice on statistical modeling, coding, and research reproducibility. Prior to joining the center, I worked as a research scientist at the University of Notre Dame and the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.

Education

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
What is ggplot2?

Definition: ggplot2 is an R package for creating data visualizations based on the grammar of graphics.
Created by: Hadley Wickham
First released: 2007

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Advantages:

Produces visually appealing and customizable plots.
Based on a coherent grammar of graphics, making it easy to understand and use.
Works well with tidy data principles.
Offers extensive documentation and a large community of users.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

Grammar of Graphics: A systematic way to describe the components of a graph, including data, aesthetics, and geometric objects.
Layered Grammar: Allows you to build complex plots by adding layers of data and visual elements.
Faceting: Easily create multiple plots based on subsets of your data.
Themes: Customize the appearance of your plots with built-in or custom themes.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Why Use ggplot2?

There are many package that build on ggplot to work with specific kinds of data, e.g.;

survminer for survival analysis
ggcorrplot for correlation plots
gganimate make plot animations

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Basic Syntax Overview

ggplot() function: Initializes a ggplot object.
data Can be given either directly or through a pipe
aes() function: Specifies aesthetic mappings between data variables and visual properties.
geom_*() functions: Add geometric objects (points, lines, bars, etc.) to your plot.
facet_*() functions: Facet your plot by one or more variables.
theme() function: Customize the appearance of your plot.

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format
Columns need top be in format you want to plot


library(tidyverse)

tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweek1week2week3week4A10121411B12151520

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Data prep for plotting

Generally data needs to be in a long format


df <- tibble(location = c("A", "B"),
       week1 = c(10, 12),
       week2 = c(12, 15),
       week3 = c(14, 15),
       week4 = c(11,  20)) %>% 
  pivot_longer(names_to = "week", values_to = "count", week1:week4) %>%  
  mutate(week = as.numeric(str_remove(week, pattern = "week"))) 


df %>% 
  flextable::flextable()

locationweekcountA110A212A314A411B112B215B315B420

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (1)

basic plot


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (2)

change size of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (3)

change the color of the dots


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5)

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (4)

change axis


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22))

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
First simple plot (5)

change labels and theme


ggplot(data = df, aes(x = week, y = count, color = location)) +
  geom_point(size = 5) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0,22)) +
  labs(x = "sample week", y = "tick count") +
  theme_classic()

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text: Zack’s heatmap

title: Introduction to ggplot2
text:
Zack’s heatmap (code)

ggplot(data = heatmap_data, aes(x = week, y = transect, fill = density)) +
    geom_tile() +
    facet_grid(treatment_type ~ .) +
    scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "black") +
    guides(fill = guide_colorbar(title = "Density of nymphs per 1000m2"))  +
    labs(y = "") +
    theme(legend.position = "bottom",
                legend.key.size = unit(1, 'cm')) +
    theme(panel.background = element_blank(),
                plot.background = element_blank(),
                axis.text = element_text(size = 19))+
    geom_vline(xintercept = c(1.5, 5.5), linetype = "dashed", size = 1.5) +
    theme(axis.title = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.text = element_text(size = 16),
                legend.title = element_text(size = 19),
                title = element_text(size = 15),
                strip.text = element_text(size = 15))

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (1)

Keep an as raw as possible version
Consider making your original data file read-only



keep in a ‘save’ format
Not excel format - transferring between platforms can cause an issue (e.g. dates)
csv, tsv, maybe text



Don’t make changes to this raw data
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (2)

Content of columns in correct data type and units

character (e.g, “a”, “swc”)
numeric (real or decimal) (e.g, 2, 2.0)
logical (FALSE, TRUE)
integer (e.g, 2L, as.integer(3))
complex (e.g, 1 + 0i, 1 + 4i) <- These can be annoying




R sees logical as 0/1 (FALSE/TRUE). This can be handy during coding.
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (3)

Try to have content of columns in correct data type and units
An example why this can is important



speciesspeedspeed_mphelphant24.0 mph24.0mouse8.1 mph8.1cheetah74.6 mph74.7
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
Keep raw version safe !!!











dayHouse_AHouse_BHouse_CHouse_DHouse_E1.010.02.01.011.014.02.010.010.012.014.02.03.08.09.05.06.08.04.04.04.04.02.011.05.02.02.02.04.01.0

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
Keep raw version safe !!!
Lyric: “House E used pesticides and should be excluded for this study”


 raw_data_wide %>% 
  select(-House_E) %>%    ## The owners used pesticides during the trials
      flextable::flextable() %>% 
      flextable::colformat_double(digits = 1)

dayHouse_AHouse_BHouse_CHouse_D1.010.02.01.011.02.010.010.012.014.03.08.09.05.06.04.04.04.04.02.05.02.02.02.04.0
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data (4)

Use a scripted program not only for analysis, but also for data cleaning and data wrangling
reproducible
Keep raw version safe !!!
Lyric: “House E used pesticides and should be excluded for this study”
A few months later…


Lyric: “I changed my mind about house_E”


“Sorry I deleted that data” versus “Let me rerun code”
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Wide format versus long format




dayHouse_AHouse_BHouse_CHouse_DHouse_E1.010.02.01.011.014.02.010.010.012.014.02.03.08.09.05.06.08.04.04.04.04.02.011.05.02.02.02.04.01.0



wide often easier for recording
long often required for analysis

title: Good data practices
text:
Data documentation (1)







Tip


You know details of project and data structure (at this moment), but what about future you or others.
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Data documentation (2)

README

one per dataset
provide a title for the dataset
brief description per column
publicly available data may need more details
https://guides.lib.uci.edu/datamanagement/readme

Metadata

often 1 per study
information does generally not change

e.g. details on study sites

data about data




https://datadryad.org/stash/best_practices https://data.research.cornell.edu/content/readme
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming

Use descriptive names for folders, files and variables


Understandable but not to long

m1 versus glm_count_full
data versus tick_counts_EA








Tip


While a computer will ultimately run your code, it’ll be read by humans, so write code intended for humans!
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

title: Good data practices
text:
Naming

Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’
crumbs: Introduction into good data and coding practices

styles

camelCase
PascalCase
snake_case



be consistent

section: How to deal with R (programming) errors
text:
How to deal with R (programming) errors

don’t get frustrated by error messages
read the error message
google the error message
google solutions or use ChatGPT
trial and error

it works –> go back to your analysis

error -> go back to 1.

title: David Jansen
text: The site is created with Rstudio and Quarto (https://quarto.org/docs/websites). It uses a Docker container to manage R packages and is maintained through github actions.
The LaTeX code that was used to create this CV can be found here.

title: Publications list
text:
References

Akinyi, Mercy Y, Bobby Jansen, David And Habig, Laurence R Gesquiere, Susan C Alberts, and Elizabeth A Archie. 2019. “Costs and Drivers of Helminth Parasite Infection in Wild Female Baboons.” Journal of Animal Ecology 88 (7): 1029–43.


Björk, Johannes R, Mauna R Dasari, Kim Roche, Laura Grieneisen, Trevor J Gould, Jean-Christophe Grenier, Vania Yotova, Neil Gottel, Laurence R Jansen, David And Gesquiere, et al. 2022. “Synchrony and Idiosyncrasy in the Gut Microbiome of Wild Baboons.” Nature Ecology & Evolution 6 (7): 955–64.


Gordon, Jacob B, Niki H Jansen, David And Learn, and Susan C Alberts. 2022. “Ordinal Dominance Rank Assignments: Protocol for the Amboseli Baboon Research Project.” Avaialable at: Https://Amboselibaboons. Nd. Edu/Downloads/, Accessed Feb 23: 2023.


Grieneisen, Laura, Mauna Dasari, Trevor J Gould, Johannes R Björk, Jean-Christophe Grenier, Vania Yotova, Neil Jansen, David And Gottel, Jacob B Gordon, Niki H Learn, et al. 2021. “Gut Microbiome Heritability Is Nearly Universal but Environmentally Contingent.” Science 373 (6551): 181–86.


Grieneisen, L, M Dasari, TJ Gould, JR Bjork, J Grenier, V Yotova, D Jansen, et al. 2020. “Heritability of the Gut Microbiome in Wild Baboons (Papio Cynocephalus).” In American Journal of Primatology. Vol. 82. WILEY 111 RIVER ST, HOBOKEN 07030-5774, NJ USA.


Habig, Bobby, Jansen, David A, Mercy Y Akinyi, Laurence R Gesquiere, Susan C Alberts, and Elizabeth A Archie. 2019. “Multi-Scale Predictors of Parasite Risk in Wild Male Savanna Baboons (Papio Cynocephalus).” Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology 73: 1–16.


Jansen, David A. 2003. “The Contribution of Floodplains to the Ecology of Large Herbivores.” PhD thesis, University of Wageningen.


———. 2013a. “Diet Selection in Goats.” PhD thesis, University of Wageningen.


———. 2013b. “Self-Organising Spatial Patterns in Mussel Beds.” PhD thesis, University of Wageningen.


———. 2013c. “Vocal Communication in the Banded Mongoose (Mungos Mungo).” PhD thesis, University of Zurich.


Jansen, David A, Michael A Cant, and Marta B Manser. 2012. “Segmental Concatenation of Individual Signatures and Context Cues in Banded Mongoose (Mungos Mungo) Close Calls.” BMC Biology 10: 1–11.


———. 2013. “Testing for Vocal Individual Discrimination in Adult Banded Mongooses.” Journal of Zoology. PhD thesis.


Jansen, David A, Frank van Langevelde, Willem F de Boer, and Kevin P Kirkman. 2007. “Optimisation or Satiation, Testing Diet Selection Rules in Goats.” Small Ruminant Research 73 (1-3): 160–68.


Manser, Marta B, Jansen, David A Jansen, Beke Graw, Linda I Hollén, Christophe AH Bousquet, Roman D Furrer, and Aliza Le Roux. 2014. “Vocal Complexity in Meerkats and Other Mongoose Species.” In Advances in the Study of Behavior, 46:281–310. Academic Press.


Roche, Kimberly E, Johannes R Bjork, Mauna R Dasari, Laura Grieneisen, Trevor J Jansen, David And Gould, Laurence R Gesquiere, Luis B Barreiro, Susan C Alberts, Ran Blekhman, et al. 2023. “Universal Gut Microbial Relationships in the Gut Microbiome of Wild Baboons.” Elife 12: e83152.


Townsend, Simon W, Sonja E Koski, Richard W Byrne, Katie E Slocombe, Balthasar Bickel, Markus Boeckle, Ines Braga Goncalves, et al. 2017. “Exorcising g Rice’s Ghost: An Empirical Approach to Studying Intentional Communication in Animals.” Biological Reviews 92 (3): 1427–33.

title: Introduction into git
text: What is version control

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is version control

Keep track and saves all you changes to code
Good backup source
Easier to fix mistakes
Code is open and easy to share
Multiple people working on the same code

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is Git

Git is a version control system that allows developers to track changes in their code
installed on your own computer
controlled through mostly terminal

but e.g. Rstudio have systems to make it easier

there are alternatives but git is most common (at least in science)

title: Introduction into git
text:
What is GitHub

GitHub is a web-based hosting service for git repositories.
Enables you to store and share code for different projects
More advanced

Github actions
Github pages
Together they can e.g. build and host a webpage (e.g. this presentation).

title: Introduction into git
text: Let’s have some fun !!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Let’s have some fun
Sorry I forgot I am in an mosquito lab

text:

Make an account

https://github.com/signup

Install git

Github student account
private repositories

title: Introduction into git
text:
Make a repository

Method 1 (easy)

Create repository on github
https://github.com

Method 2 (harder)

use Git Repo

Create a repository from command line
Not today

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal

‘Easy’ start with git bash

https://education.github.com/git-cheat-sheet-education.pdf
Let’s go to the terminal.

title: Introduction into git
text:
Terminal
echo "# training_repo" >> README.md
git init
git add README.md
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin git@github.com:david-awam-jansen/training_repo.git
git push -u origin main

Terminal
git status

text:
Naming

Use descriptive names for folders, files and variables


Understandable but not to long

m1 versus glm_count_full
data versus tick_counts_EA








Tip


While a computer will ultimately run your code, it’ll be read by humans, so write code intended for humans!

title: Introduction into git
text:
Naming

Be aware on naming rules of programs

Avoid special characters ($, @, *)
Avoid name of functions
No spaces !!
Case-sensitive (e.g. R) versus case insensitive (SQL)
R (and many other languages) names can’t start with numbers and does not like spaces
‘car speed in miles per hour’ versus ‘car speed (mph)’ versus car_speed_mph’
